node.title: Man's excruciating penis pain found to be rare COVID side effect
node.description: Doctors had to drain blood from his genitals using a needle.
node.content: ["Excruciating penis pain is a rare side effect of COVID-19, it's been found.", "The discovery comes after a man, 41, presented in hospital in Iran having suffered penile pain for three days, the New York Post reported.", "The man told doctors the discomfort began when he got an erection during sex.", "He had tested positive for COVID-19 three weeks prior, a radiologist from Iran University of Medical Sciences Seyed Morteza Bagheri wrote in the journal Clinical Case Reports.", "His doctors reported nothing out of the ordinary about his COVID-19 illness and he experienced mild symptoms including a fever, cough and fatigue.", "Tests at the hospital showed the main had \"thrombosis of deep dorsal penile vein\" - blood clotting in a vein that runs across the shaft, the New York Post reported.", "They reported doctors had to drain blood from the penis using a needle to bring the stiffness down. The man was given blood-thinning medication and two months later, his symptoms completely disappeared.", "Everything is in working order \"down there\" Morteza Bagheri wrote.", "The Heart Research Institute NZ website says current data shows COVID causes abnormalities in blood clotting.", "\"Patients with severe COVID-19 infection appear to be at greater risk of developing blood clots in the veins and arteries.\"", "This could be due to the virus directly impacting the cell lining on our blood vessels, as well as a response to being particularly unwell and immobile from the virus."]
